case_name: Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 464 of 1964 filed by Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 464 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the Award

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 29, 1962 of the Third Industrial Tribunal in Case No. VIII-197 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated the September 29, 1962 of the Third Industrial Tribunal in Case No. VIII- 197 of 1960.

facts.text: Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd. granted special leave to appeal on January 21, 1963

anchor.surface_text: The Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd. was granted on January 21, 1963 special leave to appeal against the award of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal dated September 29, 1962.

facts.text: Third Industrial Tribunal set aside dismissal of twelve workmen and ordered reinstatement with continuity of service and 25% back wages

anchor.surface_text: By that award the Tribunal set aside the dismissal from service of twelve workmen of the Company and ordered their reinstatement with companytinuity of service but awarded only 25 per cent of the back wages etc.

facts.text: Dispute referred by Government of West Bengal on July 20, 1960 under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred by the Government of West Bengal on July 20, 1960 under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Workmen dismissed after domestic enquiry commenced on February 4, 1960 which was carried on ex parte

anchor.surface_text: The workmen were dismissed after a domestic enquiry companymenced on February 4, 1960 which was carried on exparte because these workmen did number choose to be present.

facts.text: Tribunal held that the enquiry was not proper

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the enquiry was number proper and some of the witnesses were re-examined before the Tribunal

facts.text: Eleven workmen belonged to Dual Auto Mill and twelfth to Baby Mill

anchor.surface_text: Eleven of these workmen belonged to what is known as the Dual Auto Mill and the twelfth was working on what is described as the Baby Mill.

facts.text: Workmen and others stopped work from January 21, 1960 and placed under suspension on 25/27th January

anchor.surface_text: These workmen and several others stopped work from January 21, 1960 and they were placed under suspension on 25/27th January.

facts.text: Ten other workmen dismissed but taken back on intercession of Government of Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Ten other workmen were also dismissed but they were taken back on the intercession of the Government of Bengal.

facts.text: Output of Dual Auto Mills fell from 17 batches to 15 and less from January 12, 1960

anchor.surface_text: From January 12, there was a fall in the output of the Dual Auto Mills at all the three shifts. The number of batches fell from 17 to 15 and later still further.

facts.text: Warnings issued on January 15, 1960 to workmen for going slow

anchor.surface_text: On January 15, 1960 warnings were issued to these workmen that they were going slow and that go slow action was misconduct under cl. 10 XVI  of the Companys Standing Orders

facts.text: Union No. 4145 registered but not recognised by Company; Union No. 729 recognised

anchor.surface_text: This Union was registered but it was number recognised by the Company. Another Union which bears No. 729 and goes under the, name of Dunlop Rubber Factory Labour Union was recognised

facts.text: Dismissed workmen belonged to Union No. 4145

anchor.surface_text: There was great rivalry between the two Unions and the dismissed workmen belonged to Union No. 4145.

facts.text: Raghunandan Das absent on leave from January 12 to January 19, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Raghunandan Das was absent on leave from January 12 to January 19, 1960.

facts.text: Quarrel between Chandramma Chaube and Raghunandan Das on January 21, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, it seems that these two workmen quarreled on January 21 and Raghunandan Das abused Chandramma Chaube and also Union No. 4145.

facts.text: Members of Union 4145 threatened to stop work unless Raghunandan Das transferred

anchor.surface_text: Immediately the members of 4145 Union threatened to stop work unless Raghunandan Das was removed from the Dual Auto Mill and transferred to another Department.

facts.text: Dual Auto Mills remained closed or worked below capacity after refusal to work

anchor.surface_text: As a result the Dual Auto Mills either remained closed or worked much below their capacity.

facts.text: Enquiry commenced by Mr. P. K. Maitra, ex parte, found workmen guilty of go slow

anchor.surface_text: One Mr. P. K. Maitra companymenced enquiry into the charges... As a result of the enquiry, which was ex parte, Mr. Maitra held that these workmen were going slow

facts.text: Company ordered dismissal and sought permission under s. 33 of Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: The Company accordingly ordered their dismissal seeking at the same time the permission of the Tribunal under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act

facts.text: Government of West Bengal interceded, Company took back 10 workmen selected by Union 4145

anchor.surface_text: Later, the Government of West Bengal took interest... the Company agreed to take back 10 of the workmen leaving it to Union No. 4145 to select the persons

facts.text: Tribunal held stoppage of work amounted to technically illegal strike

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, held that the stoppage of work by the workmen amounted to strike as there were proceedings pending before the Tribunal, but since the strike was peaceful

facts.text: Court found go slow deliberate from January 12, 1960 by Union 4145 workmen

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the workmen were going slow from January 12, 1960, that the charge of go slow was incorporated in the charge-sheet read with the warning letter

facts.text: Court held enquiry not vitiated by refusal of representation from unrecognised union

anchor.surface_text: Refusal to allow representation by any Union unless the Standing Orders confer that right does number vitiate the proceedings.

facts.text: Court set aside Tribunal's order and upheld Company's dismissal

anchor.surface_text: We think that the order passed by the Tribunal should be vacated and the order passed by the Company ought to be accepted.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated the September 29, 1962 of the Third Industrial Tribunal in Case No. VIII- 197
The Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd. was granted on January 21, 1963 special leave to appeal against the award of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal dated September 29, 1962.
This dispute was referred by the Government of West Bengal on July 20, 1960 under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
The Company accordingly ordered their dismissal seeking at the same time the permission of the Tribunal under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: Under the Standing Orders of the Company go slow is a major misconduct. VIII  and engaging or inciting others to engage in irregular or unjustified or illegal strikes malingering or slowing down of work  cl. XVI .

issues.text: Whether the workmen were charged with go-slow action under the Standing Orders and whether such go-slow was proved

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was wrong in holding that the workmen were number charged with go slow action and therefore companyld number be dismissed on the finding that they were guilty of go slow. Under the Standing Orders of the Company go slow is a major misconduct. Clauses  VIII  and  XVI  of Standing Order 10 deal with insubordination or disobedience or failure whether alone or in companybination with others, to carry out any lawful and reasonable or proper order of a Superior  cl. VIII  and engaging or inciting others to engage in irregular or unjustified or illegal strikes malingering or slowing down of work  cl. XVI .

issues.text: Whether the domestic enquiry was vitiated by refusal to permit representation by a member of the unrecognized Union No. 4145, amounting to denial of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Under the Standing Orders of this Company representation companyld only be by a member of a recognised Union but as Union No. 729 was anathema to the members of Union No. 4145 they would number avail of the services of any member of that Union. Under the Standing Orders it is clearly provided that at such enquiries only a representative of a Union which is registered under the Indian Trade Union Act

issues.text: Whether the Industrial Tribunal was justified in interfering with the dismissal order by acting as a court of appeal and re-appreciating the evidence

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in this case the Tribunal was number justified in interfering. It has acted as a companyrt of appeal in scrutinizing the evidence and in reaching companyclusions of its own. We are also satisfied that the companyclusions reached by it were number justified on the evidence in the case.

issues.text: Whether the dismissal of the workmen was justified given the go-slow, illegal strike, and pendency of proceedings requiring permission under s.33 of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: The Company accordingly ordered their dismissal seeking at the same time the permission of the Tribunal under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act and tendering one months wages to each workman. Later, the Government of West Bengal took interest in the matter and at the intercession of the Government the Company agreed to take back 10 of the workmen

holdings.text: The workmen were going slow from January 12, 1960, that the charge of go slow was incorporated in the charge-sheet read with the warning letter and that it was fully substantiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Output records showed fall from 17 to 15 batches; warnings explicitly mentioned go-slow as misconduct under cl.10(XVI); charge-sheet invoked relevant clauses; workmen denied in replies; log books noted slow work; explanation of mixture quality false as production normalized later.

holdings.text: Under the Standing Orders of the Company go slow is a major misconduct under Clauses VIII and XVI of Standing Order 10.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was wrong in holding that the workmen were number charged with go slow action and therefore companyld number be dismissed on the finding that they were guilty of go slow. Under the Standing Orders of the Company go slow is a major misconduct. Clauses  VIII  and  XVI  of Standing Order 10

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses cover insubordination/disobedience (VIII) and slowing down of work (XVI); distinguished from minor offences.

holdings.text: Refusal to allow representation by any Union unless the Standing Orders confer that right does not vitiate the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Refusal to allow representation by any Union unless the Standing Orders confer that right does number vitiate the proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing orders limit representation to recognised unions registered under Indian Trade Unions Act; workmen insisted on their unrecognised union; no general right beyond standing orders.

holdings.text: There is no right to representation as such unless the Company by its Standing Orders recognises such a right.

anchor.surface_text: It has been ruled by this Court in Kalindi Ors. v. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co. Ltd. and Brook Bond India P Ltd. v. Subba Raman that there is no right to representation as such unless the Company by its Standing Orders recognises such a right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct precedent from Supreme Court cases Kalindi and Brook Bond.

holdings.text: The failure of the Enquiry Officer to accede to the request made by the employees does not introduce any serious defect in the enquiry itself, and so, the result of the said enquiry cannot be successfully challenged in the present proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: in holding domestic enquiries, reasonable opportunity should be given to the delinquent employees to meet the charge framed against them and it is desirable that at such an enquiry the employ should be given liberty to represent their case by persons of their choice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Request tied to unrecognised union recognition indirectly; company might have allowed non-union co-worker but insistence vitiated not; ex parte due to absence; natural justice not denied.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was not justified in interfering. It has acted as a court of appeal in scrutinizing the evidence and in reaching conclusions of its own.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in this case the Tribunal was number justified in interfering. It has acted as a companyrt of appeal in scrutinizing the evidence and in reaching companyclusions of its own.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Domestic enquiry fair, charge proved, punishment justified; tribunal re-appreciated evidence impermissibly.

holdings.text: No outside agency should impose its will unless the action of the Company is lacking in bona fides or is manifestly perverse or unfair.

anchor.surface_text: No outside agency should impose its will unless the action of the Company is lacking in bona fides or is manifestly perverse or unfair. There is nothing to indicate this.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of mala fides, perversity or unfairness in company action; management prerogative in discipline.

holdings.text: The order passed by the Tribunal should be vacated and the order passed by the Company ought to be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the order passed by the Tribunal should be vacated and the order passed by the Company ought to be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Go-slow major misconduct proved; enquiry valid; illegal strike worsened; s.33 permission sought; no discrimination by company.

holdings.text: The Company should seriously consider whether Union No. 4145 should not also be recognised.

anchor.surface_text: But as that Union seems to be the stronger of the two Unions the Company should seriously consider whether Union No. 4145 should number also be recognised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Larger membership; rivalry disturbs peace; non-binding suggestion for industrial harmony.
